This textbook is frequently recommended (https://www.amazon.com/Algorithmic-Game-Theory-Noam-Nisan/dp/0521872820). 

This other book is pretty good, but not as comprehensive (https://www.amazon.com/Twenty-Lectures-Algorithmic-Game-Theory/dp/131662479X)

These set of notes are pretty fantastic: http://theory.stanford.edu/~tim/f13/f13.html

This other book is pretty good, but not as comprehensive (https://www.amazon.com/Twenty-Lectures-Algorithmic-Game-Theory/dp/131662479X)

children.subject: I would say more of 1. (and maybe slightly of 2.) -- enough to understand the work behind this article and this one.

I'm not an expert on the pure complexity proofs, but I know they exist and roughly what they say.

For the pure complexity proofs, you need to know the End of the Line theorem, and read the classic paper: https://people.csail.mit.edu/costis/journal_ver10.pdf

But since this paper is pretty old, I'm assuming you also want to read the one about inapproximability: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1405.3322.pdf

However, these papers require an amazingly large amount of context to truly understand the intuitions (and I'm not saying I have these intuitions 100% either), because much of their visualizations involve vector fields and flows, which are related to the continuous versions of no-regret algorithms (which you might also wanna read because they're the standard algorithms to reach equilibria and have connections to all of online convex optimization). The proofs also are worst-case complexity proofs (and also force you to read up on the PCP theorem which takes up a long time, but maybe worthwhile), so they don't give much intuition about what sets of games are actually hard. 

The best way to visualize which class of games are hard in a structured setting is this: https://arxiv.org/abs/1005.2405. It uses fancy algebraic topology terms, but roughly it says that normal form games are just discretized curves, and when you look at differences (which corresponds to players changing actions), this is like looking at flows on curves. Flows are usually a sum of basic cyclic flows and gradient flows of a potential function, and the parts that make finding equilibria hard in a game are the cyclic flows that make it hard to converge. 

Interestingly enough, Deepmind applied these concepts to GANs and got ICML 2018 runner up: https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.05642

For the intuition behind these papers, should I be looking at grad courses (such as CS270) or is it self-studyable for someone who has taken 170 (we slightly went over zero-sum games and multiplicative update weights method)?

Hi which specific part of AGT are you into? I could respond with the more modern links. 

Are you interested in, e.g.: 

1. Computational complexity of computing equilibria for normal form games? 

2. Comp. complexity of mech design? 

or more applied fields with respect to deep learning these days, like: 

3. Multi-agent RL games 

4. Evolutionary algorithms?

history.content:
Can anyone recommend / direct me to some resources on Algorithmic Game Theory, either at Berkeley or on the Internet?

I noticed that there was a seminar taught by Papadimitriou from 2011, but he has left since. Is there a possibility of this being offered again (though I've heard 294s are highly variable in offering). The homepage for TCS also mentions that faculty have worked on this subject previously.
